data: {"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3490788,"name":"Anant Raj","username":"heyanantraj","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/c89c15/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-23T17:08:59.696Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eOver the years, our team has used a limit switch at the base of our elevator to reset our motor encoder values and define the lowest position. Because the encoders tend to drift in accuracy over the course of a match, we need a reliable way to re-zero them. However, this method relies entirely on the limit switch, making it a single point of failure for the elevator. We think there must be a more robust way to achieve the same goal without depending on a limit switch. How does your team approach elevator design? Do you use limit switches with your elevator? Is it ok to rely solely on the motor encoders even though they have some error?\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-23T17:10:28.818Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":437,"reads":854,"readers_count":853,"score":2375.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"Anant Raj","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71694,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevator-with-limit-switch/483231/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3490795,"name":"Emil","username":"GronkBaby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-23T17:17:17.818Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eWe are using a distance TOF sensor to reset the position of the elevator. We are also using an absolute, throughbore encoder on the main shaft that drives the elevator up, so that it doesn’t drift in the traditional sense. I wouldn’t just rely on motor encoders, and u need a reliable way to find the initial position other than “bro the elevator is all the way down”, which didn’t work that well for us last year.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-23T17:18:56.309Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":836,"readers_count":835,"score":187.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"Emil","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64351,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/elevator-with-limit-switch/483231/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3490811,"name":"Michael limit sitches and an OR function to reset your encoder count? Then you would require two failures to lose this funtionality.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-23T18:21:12.013Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":717,"readers_count":716,"score":188.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"Eric Tate","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31332,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/elevator-with-limit-switch/483231/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3490842,"name":"","username":"Akash_Rastogi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/akash_rastogi/{size}/169937_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-23T18:23:53.191Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eI’d still go with the Time of Flight/laserCAN or absolute encoder option above. Limit switch tabs will eventually bend and you just lose positions if that happens. With the speed at which elevators accelerate and decelerate it’s hard not to accidentally smush a limit switch.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-23T18:24:24.232Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":700,"readers_count":699,"score":220.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":31332,"username":"MrT8","name":"Eric Tate","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrt8/{size}/9889_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8002,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"177 \u0026 429 | #TeamWCP| #TeamThrifty"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-with-limit-switch/483231/5","custom_user_title":"177 \u0026 429 | #TeamWCP| #TeamThrifty","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3490846,"name":"Eric Tate","username":"MrT8","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrt8/{size}/9889_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-23T18:29:56.856Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eWell - Personally I would not put a limit switch in a position to get smashed.  I prefer limit switches with wheels on their actuator lever monunted off to the side of the main mechanism. Nothing wrong with your approach though - just a bit more complicated than limit switches for many teams.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-23T18:29:56.856Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":673,"readers_count":672,"score":214.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"Eric Tate","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":8002,"username":"Akash_Rastogi","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/akash_rastogi/{size}/169937_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31332,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/elevator-with-limit-switch/483231/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3490852,"name":"Vaughn Khouri","username":"CyberClone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberclone/{size}/229178_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-23T18:37:43.010Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eAll well-built elevators should be easily stiff enough to current zero. Just run the motor backwards into the bottom end stop, wait for the stall current spike, and call it zero.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere’s really no reason to use a limit switch for something like this, it’s just an extra failure point.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-23T18:37:43.010Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":21,"reads":632,"readers_count":631,"score":576.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"Vaughn Khouri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":22}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52319,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/elevator-with-limit-switch/483231/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":19},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":22,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3490892,"name":"billbo911","username":"billbo911","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billbo911/{size}/110890_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-23T19:17:10.851Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eA decent option is to use a simple Beam Brake Sensor. Somthing like \u003ca href=\"https://www.adafruit.com/product/2168\" rel=\"noopener nofollow ugc\"\u003ethis one\u003c/a\u003e from Adafruit. Depending on your configuration, you just need it installed at a pointr where the beam is broken when the elevator reaches the bottom of travel.\u003cbr\u003e\nNo contact, no broken “switch”.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-23T19:17:29.208Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":592,"readers_count":591,"score":143.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"billbo911","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.adafruit.com/product/2168","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"IR Break Beam Sensor with Premium Wire Header Ends - 5mm LEDs : ID 2168 : Adafruit Industries, Unique \u0026 fun DIY electronics and kits","clicks":52}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":52319,"username":"CyberClone","name":"Vaughn Khouri","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberclone/{size}/229178_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4760,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"KN6MPS, WRWZ842"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-with-limit-switch/483231/8","custom_user_title":"KN6MPS, WRWZ842","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3490901,"name":"Casey Stahl - 2358 - Robot Repairman (Mentor)","username":"Case0823","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/case0823/{size}/142471_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-23T19:33:43.560Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eWe’re using a magnetic limit switch from REV this year.  And similar to you, counting with the motor encoder.  We’ve had no problems with the limit switch method in the past except for bend arms on the switch.  So protecting it is a big deal.  Which is why we’re switching to the magnetic version this year.  We’re using a 2-stage continuous elevator this year, so some other options are not as reliable for us.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-23T19:34:41.321Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":577,"readers_count":576,"score":135.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"Casey Stahl - 2358 - Robot Repairman (Mentor)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":26539,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevator-with-limit-switch/483231/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3491108,"name":"Arek","username":"EtherParts","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/etherparts/{size}/229095_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-23T22:51:36.354Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eYup, this is one of the biggest factor in developing our first product, the Limit Switch Upgrade Kit. It seems like a lot of people here would benefit from it, especially if you are having problems with tricky mounting and broken levers/switches. The best part is that you can always rely on it in a pinch. If your plan A sensor solution fails, it is the perfect plan B. If you have time, I suggest checking it out on our website, or I can just tell you more about it here too. \u003cimg src=\"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/images/emoji/google/blush.png?v=12\" title=\":blush:\" class=\"emoji\" alt=\":blush:\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"20\" Middleton","username":"Mattmidd630","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mattmidd630/{size}/266313_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-23T23:04:30.859Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eWe used those Adafruit ones on our shooter and intake last year.  Didn’t realize how sensitive they were to stray IR.  The arena lighting at the CO Regional wreaked havoc on them.  It was a rough few days.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-23T23:04:30.859Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":531,"readers_count":530,"score":186.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"Matt Cat Herder / Bottle Washer"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-with-limit-switch/483231/11","custom_user_title":"Chief Cat Herder / Bottle Washer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3491182,"name":"garyk","username":"garyk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/garyk/{size}/113200_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-23T23:48:05.051Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eWe have used these with great success, yes they are expensive:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bannerengineering.com/us/en/products/part.61651.html\" rel=\"noopener nofollow ugc\"\u003ehttps://www.bannerengineering.com/us/en/products/part.61651.html\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e$90 at Digikey:\u003ca href=\"https://www.bannerengineering.com/us/en/products/part.61651.html\" rel=\"noopener nofollow ugc\"\u003ehttps://www.bannerengineering.com/us/en/products/part.61651.html\u003c/a\u003e\u003cbr\u003e\n(Have you used your \u003cspan class=\"abbreviation\"\u003eKOP\u003ctemplate class=\"tooltiptext\" data-text=\"Kit of Parts\"\u003e\u003c/template\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Digikey voucher yet?)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThey are good at rejecting stray IR, and are easy to mount with the ring-nut in front.\u003cbr\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eIf you take the sensor off the ‘bot, put the ring-nut back on the sensor, otherwise it’ll get lost!!\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThey have a wide input voltage range 10-30VDC so you can power them off the PD board, they don’t need the \u003cspan class=\"abbreviation\"\u003eVRM\u003ctemplate class=\"tooltiptext\" data-text=\"Voltage Regulator Module\"\u003e\u003c/template\u003e\u003c/span\u003e. They have an indicator light for “power on” and another for when it’s triggered. They work up to 45 CM and have an adjustment for sensitivity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEasy to wire: Blue wire to ground, brown to +12 on PD board, black to the signal input of your roboRIO DIO port. The roboRIO signal port already has the pull-up resistor it needs. We solder red and black wires to the brown and blue wires to avoid confusion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThey’re on the Web at remarkably lower prices but I don’t know if they’re fakes, or quality rejects from the manufacturer?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf you have a bug or electrical problem you don’t have to worry about your elevator smashing a beam of IR \u003cimg Khouri","username":"CyberClone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberclone/{size}/229178_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T03:12:42.447Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cspan class=\"abbreviation\"\u003eFRC\u003ctemplate class=\"tooltiptext\" data-text=\"FIRST Robotics Competition\"\u003e\u003c/template\u003e\u003c/span\u003e just turns out to be well suited to this approach, because modern brushless motors allow you to set a current limit on the fly and read the current accurately. So you can set up a routine that sets the current limit low during the homing, so as to not damage anything.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe’ve used this approach on many of our robots in the past few years and I can name numerous examples from powerhouse teams. 1678 2022 hood comes to mind as something they explicitly called out in their behind the bumpers interview.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eI can also think of some real world examples; the Prusa Mk3s family of printers all do this to home their X Y and Z axis.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T03:12:42.447Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":460,"readers_count":459,"score":347.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"Vaughn Khouri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":31332,"username":"MrT8","name":"Eric Tate","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrt8/{size}/9889_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":15}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52319,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/elevator-with-limit-switch/483231/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":14},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":15,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3491357,"name":"Christopher Coleman","username":"CColeman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ccoleman/{size}/259753_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T03:15:38.561Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eHow much will a neo drift over a match? Barber","username":"hydrogenh1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/dec6dc/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T03:42:45.761Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eI’d second this approach. I just wrote a routine for my team’s elevator today which performed this exact maneuver, waiting until high current is reached for a certain amount of time (that way the current spike from accelerating the elevator is filtered out).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother nice aspect of this approach is that it can be more precise than limit switches. The motors will zero out their backlash, and there’s no region where the switch is partially depressed. You just have to make sure you don’t move the elevator too fast.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T03:42:55.459Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":444,"readers_count":443,"score":158.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"Hale Barber","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":52319,"username":"CyberClone","name":"Vaughn Khouri","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberclone/{size}/229178_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":71654,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/elevator-with-limit-switch/483231/17","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3491399,"name":"Vaughn Khouri","username":"CyberClone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberclone/{size}/229178_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T04:24:02.595Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eIt’s dead simple - I just looked at our 2023 code:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode class=\"lang-auto\"\u003epublic Command runCurrentZeroing() {\n    return this.run(() -\u0026gt; io.setVoltage(-1.0))\n        .until(() -\u0026gt; inputs.elevatorCurrentAmps[0] \u0026gt; 40.0)\n        .finallyDo(() -\u0026gt; io.resetEncoder(0.0))\n        .beforeStarting(() -\u0026gt; io.setLockServoRotation(0.2));\n  }\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOf course, there’s some minor abstraction here - if you’re curious the file is \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/HighlanderRobotics/Crescendo/blob/main/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/elevator/ElevatorSubsystem.java\" rel=\"noopener nofollow ugc\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe didn’t bother to set the current limit lower because our elevator was easily stiff enough to not need it. The extra command is just for our elevator lockout that we used for climb.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T04:24:02.595Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":29,"reads":441,"readers_count":440,"score":263.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"Vaughn this is how a variety of 3D printers are engineered this way.   PRUSA uses “stall guard” to home the print head for x and y axis as it detects uptic in current.  This method is reliable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSomething to consider is adjusting the feed rate before nearing zero.  When my printer does this, it isn’t at full speed…\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":41,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T04:36:18.736Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":444,"readers_count":443,"score":133.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":483231,"topic_slug":"elevator-with-limit-switch","display_username":"Mentor Matt Stemple","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":52319,"username":"CyberClone","name":"Vaughn Khouri","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberclone/{size}/229178_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20113,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor Matt 3257"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-with-limit-switch/483231/19","custom_user_title":"Mentor Matt 3257","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3491419,"name":"Eyup Akgun","username":"EyupAkgun","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eyupakgun/{size}/239861_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T05:15:56.487Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eIn Charged Up we were driving the cascade elevator with two neo’s. The neo encoders and the mechanical switch + magnetic switch (even though the intake connected to the elevator was too heavy and the build quality of the elevator was not good) gave us near perfect accuracy. (The mechanical switch was used to reset the encoder data and the magnetic switch was used to verify that the elevator closed)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eYes, even though others think “too many parts, too many errors”, if it can work without errors and verify each other even in primitive ways, and if it can come out of Archimedes’23 without any problems (hello to 23 archimedes veterans o7), I think we should not worry about it too much \u003cimg src=\"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/images/emoji/google/hugs.png?v=12\" title=\":hugs:\" class=\"emoji\" alt=\":hugs:\" loading=\"lazy\" width=\"20\"
